Probably the best way to quantify the difference would be to implement th=
e kind of random search that you are interested in and then compare it in t=
he same domain (and other domains, if you want to be thorough).  Of course,=
 if you found that any type of completely random process consistently outpe=
rforms fitness significantly in reasonable domains (as novelty does) it wou=
ld be a huge shock.   

You suggest that the random search that we implemen=
ted is worse than the kind of random search that you describe.  I could be =
wrong, but I don't think there is an a priori reason to believe that any gi=
ven totally uninformed process is better than another.  You note that our r=
andom search may be more "uneven," which could be true, but there is no a p=
riori reason to believe that being "even" is better for a given domain.  Ge=
nerally, even with totally random searches you are facing a kind of no free=
 lunch situation.

Probably the most important question underlying your cur=
iosity is why we would expect novelty to be better than random.  There are =
many answers to this question, but perhaps one helpful insight is that nove=
lty is an informative gradient.  That is, quite the opposite of random sear=
ch, novelty is information-rich, which means that the novelty metric tells =
us a lot about how different points in the search space relate to each othe=
r.  In fact, one way to understand the relationship among random, fitness, =
and novelty, is to realize that fitness actually provides less information =
than novelty, putting it between random and novelty on the scale of informa=
tion-richness.  The reason fitness provides less information is that many b=
ehaviors that are different from each other receive the same fitness, where=
as novelty search would notice their difference.  Thus, in fitness-based se=
arch, moving among such conflated behaviors is similar to a random search, =
because there is no gradient among them.  

ken
